import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
source.af70634b:
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(20,8))
ax1 = fig.add_subplot(1, 2, 1)
ax2 = fig.add_subplot(1, 2, 2)
df.groupby('Brand Name')['Rating (Out of 5)'].count().sort_values(ascending=False).plot.bar(ax=ax1,title='Count by Brand')
df.groupby('Brand Name')['Rating (Out of 5)'].mean().sort_values(ascending=False).plot.bar(ax=ax2,title='Average Rating by Brand')

df.groupby('Model Name')['Rating (Out of 5)'].mean().sort_values(ascending=False).head(30).plot.bar(ax=ax2,title='Average Rating by Model Name')

source.bb9dc1e3: # Who is buying what kind of fitness traker devices ?
source.1ab07c69:
![image.png](attachment:43d062bc-66d5-4cb9-bbf6-b2fb9d6915bf.png)

By clustering, I found four types of custmers. The hypothesis which I got are
* High end smart watch users (Cluster3)  They like high price and high function. And they also stick to display(OLED..) and color which they like. They are mainly APPLE or GARMIN users. They may be 'Innovators' or 'Early Adopters' of smart watch.
* Middle end smart watch users(Cluster1)  They are not so stick to function and design than Cluster3. They are APPLE, GARMIN, SUMSONG or Huawei users. They may be 'Early Majorities'
* Early fitness tracker device users(Cluster2) They are buying the device to track the fitness more than other purposes, and not so stick to brands than Cluster3 and Cluster1. So they seem to be focusing on the track more than Cluster3 or 1. So their brands are not only above brands but also FOSSIL, FitBit or Oppo etc...
* Normal fitness tracker device users(Cluster0) They are just buying the device to track the fitness. So they seem to stick to price, and function to track.
